Issues.Title: Dynamic responsive variants (max-*/min-*) do not honor custom breakpoints defined in @theme static, while unprefixed variants do
Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?** v4.x (verified on at least 4.0.6) **What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?** Nuxt UI (Nuxt 3+), Tailwind CLI, and also tested with Vite 6.1.0 **What version of Node.js are you using?** v20.x **What browser are you using?** Any (problem is about generated CSS) **What operating system are you using?** Tested on macOS and Linux (occurs in all environments) **Reproduction URL** [Reproduction repository](https://github.com/ivan-angjelkoski/tailwindcss-breakpoint-static-bug-demo) **Describe your issue** When defining custom breakpoints using `@theme static` in CSS (for example: ```css @theme static { --breakpoint-sm: 640px; --breakpoint-md: 768px; } ``` ) ...the responsive classes like `sm:` use my custom breakpoints as expected. However, functional responsive variants like `max-sm:` and `min-md:` fall back to Tailwind's built-in defaults instead of using my custom values. **Example:** ```css @theme static { --breakpoint-sm: 640px; --breakpoint-md: 768px; } ``` In markup: ```
Test
``` **Generates:** - `sm:p-2` ‚Üí `@media (min-width: 640px)` (correct) - `max-sm:p-3` ‚Üí `@media (max-width: 639px)` (fallbacks to Tailwind default 639px, not the static value) - `min-md:p-4` ‚Üí `@media (min-width: 768px)` (fallbacks to Tailwind default 768px, not the static value) Unprefixed breakpoints (`sm:`, `md:`, etc.) work as expected, but dynamic variants `max-*` and `min-*` ignore the custom definitions when using `@theme static`. If you use `@theme` or `@theme default`, this problem disappears, but using `static` is required for my scenario (for Nuxt UI or integration constraints). **Why this matters** - Projects using Tailwind CSS v4+ with custom breakpoint management in CSS need all responsive variants to respect user-defined breakpoints regardless of theme block type. - Duplicating breakpoints between `@theme static` and non-static theme blocks is not a sustainable workaround. **Steps to reproduce** 1. Use `@theme static` to define custom breakpoints (e.g., `--breakpoint-sm: 640px;`) 2. Add classes such as `sm:p-2`, `max-sm:p-3`, and `min-md:p-4` in your markup 3. Build and inspect the generated CSS and see that max/min prefixed variants use default values **Expected:** All responsive variants use my custom breakpoints, regardless of theme block method. **Actual:** Only unprefixed variants do; `max-*` and `min-*` do not support custom statically-defined breakpoints. See also: https://github.com/tailwindlabs/tailwindcss/discussions/23347 /cc @ivan-angjelkoski
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Dynamic responsive variants (max-*/min-*) do not honor custom breakpoints defined in @theme static, while unprefixed variants do" (#19446)

Issues.Title: `color-mix()` should not be transpiled with custom properties
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

v4.1.18

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

vite, reproducible in playground

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

n/a

**What browser are you using?**

n/a

**What operating system are you using?**

n/a

**Reproduction URL**

https://play.tailwindcss.com/vfK8S6Q1Ry?file=css (look at the class `.via-ease-in-sine` in the "Generated CSS" panel)

**Describe your issue**

I've got a custom directive using `color-mix` with two custom properties, as [described here](https://github.com/tailwindlabs/tailwindcss/discussions/19441).

## What I expected

I'd expect no transpilation to happen if I use custom properties in color-mix:

```css
.via-ease-in-sine {
  --tw-gradient-via-stops: var(--tw-gradient-position),
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 0%) 0%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 0.8%) 8.1%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 2.9%) 15.5%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 6.2%) 22.5%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 10.1%) 29%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 14.8%) 35.3%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 20.1%) 41.2%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 26.2%) 47.1%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 32.8%) 52.9%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 40%) 58.8%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 47.8%) 64.7%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 56.6%) 71%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 66.3%) 77.5%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 77.1%) 84.5%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 88.7%) 91.9%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 100%) 100%;
}

```

## What actually happened

my color-mix directives are being transpiled, and in a way that makes no sense. Transpiled css code:

```css
.via-ease-in-sine {
    --tw-gradient-via-stops: var(--tw-gradient-position),
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 0%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 8.1%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 15.5%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 22.5%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 29%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 35.3%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 41.2%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 47.1%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 52.9%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 58.8%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 64.7%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 71%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 77.5%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 84.5%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 91.9%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 100%;
    @supports (color: color-mix(in lab, red, red)) {
      --tw-gradient-via-stops: var(--tw-gradient-position),
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 0%) 0%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 0.8%) 8.1%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 2.9%) 15.5%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 6.2%) 22.5%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 10.1%) 29%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 14.8%) 35.3%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 20.1%) 41.2%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 26.2%) 47.1%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 32.8%) 52.9%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 40%) 58.8%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 47.8%) 64.7%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 56.6%) 71%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 66.3%) 77.5%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 77.1%) 84.5%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 88.7%) 91.9%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 100%) 100%;
    }
  }
```

At first I thought this was a lightning css issue and posted [an issue on their repo](https://github.com/parcel-bundler/lightningcss/issues/1111). But then I tried it in the [lightningcss playground](https://lightningcss.dev/playground/#%7B%22minify%22%3Afalse%2C%22customMedia%22%3Afalse%2C%22cssModules%22%3Afalse%2C%22analyzeDependencies%22%3Afalse%2C%22targets%22%3A%7B%22chrome%22%3A6225920%7D%2C%22include%22%3A1113088%2C%22exclude%22%3A0%2C%22source%22%3A%22%2F*%5Cn%20*%20Add%20easing%20to%20tailwind%20linear%20gradient%20stops%5Cn%20*%5Cn%20*%20%40see%20https%3A%2F%2Fplay.tailwindcss.com%2FyMgz1p5Fx5%3Ffile%3Dcss%5Cn%20*%20%40see%20https%3A%2F%2Flarsenwork.com%2Feasing-gradients%2F%5Cn%20*%20%40see%20https%3A%2F%2Fgist.github.com%2Fmatthewbeta%2F0ef11bd907b435f101e09cc6216ad66b%5Cn%20*%2F%5Cn.via-ease-in-sine%20%7B%5Cn%20%20--tw-gradient-via-stops%3A%20var(--tw-gradient-position)%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%200%25)%200%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%200.8%25)%208.1%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%202.9%25)%2015.5%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%206.2%25)%2022.5%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2010.1%25)%2029%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2014.8%25)%2035.3%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2020.1%25)%2041.2%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2026.2%25)%2047.1%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2032.8%25)%2052.9%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2040%25)%2058.8%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2047.8%25)%2064.7%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2056.6%25)%2071%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2066.3%25)%2077.5%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2077.1%25)%2084.5%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2088.7%25)%2091.9%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%20100%25)%20100%25%3B%5Cn%7D%22%2C%22visitorEnabled%22%3Afalse%2C%22visitor%22%3A%22%7B%5Cn%20%20Color(color)%20%7B%5Cn%20%20%20%20if%20(color.type%20%3D%3D%3D%20'rgb')%20%7B%5Cn%20%20%20%20%20%20color.g%20%3D%200%3B%5Cn%20%20%20%20%20%20return%20color%3B%5Cn%20%20%20%20%7D%5Cn%20%20%7D%5Cn%7D%22%2C%22unusedSymbols%22%3A%5B%5D%2C%22version%22%3A%22local%22%7D) and couldn't reproduce it there. 

So this might be something that happens within tailwindcss, before the code is being sent to lightningcss? I don't know.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "`color-mix()` should not be transpiled with custom properties" (#19445)

Issues.Title: Memory Leak when trying to build or run dev with Vite
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Memory Leak when trying to build or run dev with Vite" (#19444)

Issues.Title: PNPM + postcss + tailwindcss v4.1.18
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

v4.1.18

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

postcss: 8.5.6
vite: 7.2.4
vue: 3.5.25

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

v22.17.1

**What browser are you using?**

All browers affected

**What operating system are you using?**

macOS

**Reproduction URL**

https://github.com/Szymon-dziewonski/pnpm-postcss-tailwindcss

**Describe your issue**

I'm a maintainer and one of the creators of [SFUI](https://docs.storefrontui.io/v2/), and now my company would like to releasea new version of our UI component library that uses TailwindCSS v4.

Everything works perfectly when packages are used with `npm`, `yarn`, and `pnpm`(only CSS). However, due to how `pnpm` operated that create packages globally or locally and link them via `node_modules/.pnpm` and in workspaces in the root `node_modules/.pnpm`, `postcss` seems to have a problem with resolving `@import` or `@plugin`.

With the given reproduction repository [link](https://github.com/Szymon-dziewonski/pnpm-postcss-tailwindcss) we can see that once the repo is checked out and all packages are installed `pnpm i` (fresh vue create + tailwindcss + tailwindcss/postcss), and run `pnpm dev`, we can see an error:
```
Can't resolve '@storefront-ui/tw-plugin-peer-next' in '/Users/szymondziewonski/Projects/pnpm-test/src'
```

Now, having said that, `tailwindcss` works as expected without `postcss` (scss file extension).

This can be easily checked by switching off import in [main.ts](https://github.com/Szymon-dziewonski/pnpm-postcss-tailwindcss/blob/main/src/main.ts) file, uncomment line 5, and comment line 6.

I believe that `tailwindcss/postcss` or `postcss` itself has a problem to resolve `node_modules` packages in `*.scss` files. 

MORE CONTEXT:
file imported from `tailwind.scss` -> `@import "@storefront-ui/vue/tailwind-config.css";` -> contains `@import "@storefront-ui/tailwind-config";` -> and this package contain tailwindcss config with content 
```
@plugin "@storefront-ui/tw-plugin-peer-next";
@plugin "@tailwindcss/typography";
@config "./index.js";

/* Mimics behaviour of removed `future.hoverOnlyWhenSupporte` flag to show hover only on devices with fine pointer (mouse, not finger) */
@custom-variant hover {
  @media (hover: hover) and (pointer: fine) {
    &:hover {
      @slot;
    }
  }
}
...
```

Sometimes also for me, `postcss` throws an error with `@import` and sometimes randomly with `@plugin` (`@plugin "@storefront-ui/tw-plugin-peer-next";`) 

In call stack we can see that it all starts with `postcss` and `tailwindcss/postcss` 
```
  3  |  @import "tailwindcss";
      at Input.error (/Users/szymondziewonski/Projects/pnpm-test/node_modules/.pnpm/postcss@8.5.6/node_modules/postcss/lib/input.js:135:16)
      at Root.error (/Users/szymondziewonski/Projects/pnpm-test/node_modules/.pnpm/postcss@8.5.6/node_modules/postcss/lib/node.js:146:32)
      at Object.Once (/Users/szymondziewonski/Projects/pnpm-test/node_modules/.pnpm/@tailwindcss+postcss@4.1.18/node_modules/@tailwindcss/postcss/dist/index.js:10:6911)
      at async LazyResult.runAsync (/Users/szymondziewonski/Projects/pnpm-test/node_modules/.pnpm/postcss@8.5.6/node_modules/postcss/lib/lazy-result.js:293:11)
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "PNPM + postcss + tailwindcss v4.1.18" (#19442)

Issues.Title: Filters doesn't work in Chrome for Android on version 114/137
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

v4.1

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

vite/playground

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

v21

**What browser are you using?**

Didn't work: Chrome v114, Kiwi Brower v137
Fine: Chrome v143, Firefox v107


**What operating system are you using?**

Android

**Describe your issue**

Any filter effect will not work properly on Chrome v114 on Android devices. But Tailwindcss v3 works fine.

Tailwindcss v4 will display filter normally when I upgrade to Chrome v143.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f676475b-6c33-49dc-a075-fbad35d49a29)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Filters doesn't work in Chrome for Android on version 114/137" (#19438)

Issues.Title: üö® [security] Update all of nextjs 16.0.7 ‚Üí 16.0.10 (patch)
Issues.Body:
üö® Your current dependencies have known security vulnerabilities üö® This dependency update fixes known security vulnerabilities. Please see the details below and assess their impact carefully. We recommend to merge and deploy this as soon as possible!
Here is everything you need to know about this update. Please take a good look at what changed and the test results before merging this pull request. ### What changed? #### ‚ú≥Ô∏è eslint-config-next (16.0.7 ‚Üí 16.0.10) Sorry, we couldn't find anything useful about this release. #### ‚ú≥Ô∏è next (16.0.7 ‚Üí 16.0.10) ¬∑ [Repo](https://github.com/vercel/next.js)
Security Advisories üö®

üö® Next Vulnerable to Denial of Service with Server Components

A vulnerability affects certain React packages for versions 19.0.0, 19.0.1, 19.1.0, 19.1.1, 19.1.2, 19.2.0, and 19.2.1 and frameworks that use the affected packages, including Next.js 15.x and 16.x using the App Router. The issue is tracked upstream as CVE-2025-55184.

A malicious HTTP request can be crafted and sent to any App Router endpoint that, when deserialized, can cause the server process to hang and consume CPU. This can result in denial of service in unpatched environments.

üö® Next Server Actions Source Code Exposure

A vulnerability affects certain React packages for versions 19.0.0, 19.0.1, 19.1.0, 19.1.1, 19.1.2, 19.2.0, and 19.2.1 and frameworks that use the affected packages, including Next.js 15.x and 16.x using the App Router. The issue is tracked upstream as CVE-2025-55183.

A malicious HTTP request can be crafted and sent to any App Router endpoint that can return the compiled source code of Server Functions. This could reveal business logic, but would not expose secrets unless they were hardcoded directly into Server Function code.

Release Notes

16.0.8

Note

This release is backporting bug fixes. It does not include all pending features/changes on canary.

Core Changes

  • Update react version in cna templates (#86950)

Credits

Huge thanks to @huozhi for helping!

Does any of this look wrong? Please let us know.

Commits

See the full diff on Github. The new version differs by 8 commits:

  • v16.0.10
  • Backport facebook/react#35351 for 16.0.9 (#87085)
  • v16.0.9
  • Update React Versions (#40)
  • Update React Version (#22)
  • Backport Next.js changes to v16.0.9 (#20)
  • v16.0.8
  • Update react version in cna templates (#86950)

All Depfu comment commands

Issues.Title: PNPM Trust Policy: High-risk trust downgrade for "tailwindcss@3.4.18" (possible package takeover)
Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

v3.4.18

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

Nuxt

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

v24.11.1

**What browser are you using?**

N/A

**What operating system are you using?**

Windows

**Describe your issue**

- Do not have a trust policy set in pnpm-workspace.yaml
- `pnpm add tailwindcss@3` (installs 3.4.18)
- Enable `trustPolicy: no-downgrade`
- Run `pnpm update tailwindcss`

‚ÄâERR_PNPM_TRUST_DOWNGRADE‚Äâ High-risk trust downgrade for "tailwindcss@3.4.18" (possible package takeover)

Trust checks are based solely on publish date, not semver. A package cannot be installed if any earlier-published version had stronger trust evidence. Earlier versions had provenance attestation, but this version has no trust evidence. A trust downgrade may indicate a supply chain incident.

Is this intendet, did you change something in your publishing process or does this indeed indicate a possible package takeover?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "PNPM Trust Policy: High-risk trust downgrade for "tailwindcss@3.4.18" (possible package takeover)" (#19423)

Issues.Title: @apply doesn't comprehend the idea of custom mixins
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

tailwindcss and @tailwindcss/vite 4.1.17

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

Vite 7.2.7

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

v24.10.0

**What browser are you using?**

Firefox/Chromium

**What operating system are you using?**

Linux

**Reproduction URL**

https://play.tailwindcss.com/jrsuOy41LK?file=css

**Describe your issue**

`@apply` is from the [functions and mixins module](https://drafts.csswg.org/css-mixins-1/); if I apply something Tailwind doesn't know, especially when it begins with `--`, Tailwind should pass it through untouched so either the browser can render it or any compat logic I have on top can work.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "@apply doesn't comprehend the idea of custom mixins" (#19422)

Issues.Title: CLI Version 4.1.17 hangs when using `--output /dev/stdout`
Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**
v4.1.17

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**
None, just the cli tool on linux

**What operating system are you using?**
NixOS (Linux)

**Reproduction URL**

this works/completes:
```bash
tailwindcss --output -
```

This just hangs:
```bash
tailwindcss --output /dev/stdout
```

**Describe your issue**

It should be functionally the same, `/dev/stdout` is a perfectly normal linux file for writing to, but tailwindcss just hangs.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "CLI Version 4.1.17 hangs when using `--output /dev/stdout`" (#19420)

Issues.Title: `@supports` is generated inside `@keyframes`
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

v4.1.17

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

Vite v7.2.6

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

20.19.1 (StackBlitz)

**What browser are you using?**

Chrome 142, 143

**What operating system are you using?**

macOS, Windows

**Reproduction URL**

https://play.tailwindcss.com/RTMJ0q6ocV?file=css

https://stackblitz.com/github/neurotech/empty-keyframes-issue?file=vite.config.ts

**Describe your issue**

```css
@keyframes gradient-success-in {
  0% {
    --tw-gradient-from: color-mix(in oklab, var(--color-emerald-600) 0%, transparent);
  }
  100% {
    --tw-gradient-from: color-mix(in oklab, var(--color-emerald-600) 20%, transparent);
  }
}
```
seems to be transformed to
```css
@keyframes gradient-success-in {
  0% {
    --tw-gradient-from: color-mix(in srgb, oklch(59.6% 0.145 163.225) 0%, transparent);
    @supports (color: color-mix(in lab, red, red)) {
      --tw-gradient-from: color-mix(in oklab, var(--color-emerald-600) 0%, transparent);
    }
  }
  100% {
    --tw-gradient-from: color-mix(in srgb, oklch(59.6% 0.145 163.225) 20%, transparent);
    @supports (color: color-mix(in lab, red, red)) {
      --tw-gradient-from: color-mix(in oklab, var(--color-emerald-600) 20%, transparent);
    }
  }
}
```
which is probably an invalid code. Browsers seem to ignore the invalid `@supports` block, but it seems lightningcss drops the whole keyframe in this case (https://github.com/parcel-bundler/lightningcss/issues/1103), which makes the whole animation to not work.

This was originally reported at https://github.com/vitejs/vite/issues/21232.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "`@supports` is generated inside `@keyframes`" (#19417)

Issues.Body: Fixes #19417

Issues.Title: Only use the last value when parsing duplicate cli arguments
Issues.Body:
## Summary

When parsing cli args, 'mri' returns an array for duplicate args, which causes unexpected results. All current arguments assume single values only. Tailwind v3 works the same way.

## Test plan

Updated tests.

Issues.Title: Safe UTF-8 Extraction and Robust <style> Block Detection in Upgrade Codemods
Issues.Body:
This PR improves the safety and robustness of Tailwind's candidate extraction and codemod migration logic in two critical areas:

1. **Rust UTF-8 Extraction**
   - Replaces `unsafe { String::from_utf8_unchecked(...) }` with safe `String::from_utf8(...)` in candidate extraction.
   - Skips any invalid UTF-8 candidates rather than panicking, providing a safer and more resilient extraction process.
2. **TypeScript Style Block Handling**
   - Switches from manual string-index logic to parsing using `node-html-parser` for detecting `<style>` blocks in codemod logic.
   - Ensures accurate detection of all `<style>` tags (including those with attributes and complex nesting), so migrations never accidentally affect style blocks.
   - Adds `node-html-parser` as a dependency to the `@tailwindcss-upgrade` package.
3. **pnpm Workspace Guidance**
   - Includes documentation for installing dependencies within the correct workspace package, avoiding root install issues.

These changes modernize the affected modules, prevent potential runtime errors from malformed files, and support robust migrations across real-world HTML/template structures.

---

## Test plan

**1. UTF-8 Candidate Extraction**
- Added test cases using invalid and valid UTF-8 byte candidates
- Ran `cargo test` to ensure the scanner skips bad candidates without panicking

**2. Codemod `<style>` Block Handling**
- Added migration examples with plain, nested, and attribute-rich `<style>` tags for multiple template syntaxes
- Confirmed classes inside `<style>` blocks are not migrated
- Ran:
  ```sh
  cd packages/@tailwindcss-upgrade
  pnpm install
  pnpm test
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Safe UTF-8 Extraction and Robust <style> Block Detection in Upgrade Codemods" (#19410)

Issues.Title: Fix formatting of path in README.md
Issues.Body:
<!--

üëã Hey, thanks for your interest in contributing to Tailwind!

**Please ask first before starting work on any significant new features.**

It's never a fun experience to have your pull request declined after investing a lot of time and effort into a new feature. To avoid this from happening, we request that contributors create a discussion to first discuss any significant new features.

For more info, check out the contributing guide:

https://github.com/tailwindcss/tailwindcss/blob/main/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md

-->

## Summary

quotation mark is not closed in README doc of the postcss preprocesor

## Test plan

not needed
